file_name: VirtuosoSurgicalInc_20191227_1-A_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_11933379_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_License Agreement.pdf

perturbation.original_text:
4.5
Late Payments: In the event that any payment due hereunder is not made when due, the payment shall accrue interest beginning
on the tenth day following the due date thereof, calculated at the annual rate of six percent (6%), the interest being compounded
on the last day of each calendar year. Each such royalty payment when made shall be accompanied by all interest so accrued.
perturbation.changed_text:
4.5
Late Payments: In the event that any payment due hereunder is not made when due, the payment shall accrue interest beginning
on the sixtieth day following the due date thereof, calculated at the annual rate of one percent (1%), the interest being compounded
on the last day of each calendar year. Each such royalty payment when made shall be accompanied by all interest so accrued.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the late payment terms to accrue interest only after 60 days and at a rate of 1% annually may violate state usury laws or prompt payment laws in Maryland, which might require interest to accrue sooner and at a higher rate, especially for commercial transactions. Some states have laws specifying acceptable interest rates for late payments in commercial contexts and setting a period by which the person must pay for the item.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Maryland Usury Law or Prompt Payment Laws

perturbation.original_text:
6.2
Termination by Company: Company may terminate this Agreement and the license granted herein, for any reason, upon giving
JHU sixty (60) days written notice under Paragraph 8.1.
perturbation.changed_text:
6.2
Termination by Company: Company may terminate this Agreement and the license granted herein, for any reason, upon giving
JHU ten (10) days written notice under Paragraph 8.1.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the termination notice period to 10 days may be considered unreasonable and contradict the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing present in Maryland contract law. A court could deem this insufficient time for JHU to find a replacement licensee or mitigate damages, especially given the complexity of the licensed technology.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Maryland Contract Law - Implied Duty of Good Faith and Fair Dealing

perturbation.original_text:
4.6
Records: The Company shall make and retain, for a period of three (3) years following the period of each report required by
Paragraph 4.4, true and accurate records, files and books of account containing all the data reasonably required for the full
computation and verification of sales and other information required in Paragraph 4.4.
perturbation.changed_text:
4.6
Records: The Company shall make and retain, for a period of one (1) year following the period of each report required by
Paragraph 4.4, true and accurate records, files and books of account containing all the data reasonably required for the full
computation and verification of sales and other information required in Paragraph 4.4.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the record retention period to one year may violate IRS guidelines or other regulations that require businesses to maintain financial records for a longer duration (e.g., 3-7 years) for audit purposes. This change creates non-compliance and could lead to legal repercussions if the records are needed for tax audits or other legal proceedings.
